verdict.summary: Composer autoload class not found errors occur when composer's generated autoloader cannot map a class name to a file. This is almost always caused by a mismatch between the PSR-4 namespace configuration in composer.json and the actual file/directory structure.

dead_ends.action: Deleting the entire vendor/ directory and running composer install without checking autoload config
dead_ends.why_fails: If the autoload PSR-4 mapping in composer.json is incorrect, reinstalling dependencies will regenerate the same broken autoloader. The issue is in the configuration, not in corrupted vendor files.

dead_ends.action: Adding explicit require_once statements for every class
dead_ends.why_fails: Bypassing the autoloader with manual require_once statements defeats the purpose of composer and creates brittle, unmaintainable dependency chains. It breaks framework conventions and will not work with dependency injection containers.

workarounds.action: Fix the PSR-4 autoload mapping in composer.json and regenerate
workarounds.how: Verify the 'autoload.psr-4' section in composer.json maps the namespace prefix to the correct directory. For example, '"App\\"': "src/"' means the App namespace maps to the src/ directory. Run 'composer dump-autoload -o' after fixing.

workarounds.action: Verify file and directory naming matches the namespace exactly
workarounds.how: Check that the class file is in the correct directory and the filename matches the class name exactly (case-sensitive on Linux). For App\Services\PaymentService, the file must be at {psr4-root}/Services/PaymentService.php with the correct namespace declaration.

leads_to.condition: when the autoload issue cascades to dependent classes that also cannot be found

preceded_by.condition: when resolving a dependency conflict results in a package version that changed its namespace structure

frequently_confused_with.distinction: Composer autoload not found is specifically about the PSR-4 autoloader mapping while generic class not found can also be caused by missing extensions or incorrect use statements
